In the ethereal realm of indie gaming, there exists a gem that defies conventional expectations and beckons players into a surreal odyssey of transformation and introspection – "Changed." This digital masterpiece, a creation of the enigmatic dragon snow, stands as an opus of minimalist brilliance, transcending the boundaries of conventional narrative to weave a mesmerizing tapestry of metamorphosis.

From the very first pixel, "Changed" submerges players into a world that pulsates with a haunting beauty. The minimalist visuals, a chiaroscuro ballet of light and shadow, form the canvas upon which the narrative unfolds. In the silence that envelops this digital realm, every pixel becomes a poignant brushstroke, crafting a surreal landscape that is as captivating as it is disconcerting.

At the heart of "Changed" lies a narrative that eschews the trappings of verbosity, opting instead for a profound, introspective silence. The protagonist, a nameless figure navigating the enigmatic corridors of change, embarks on a journey that transcends the limitations of linguistic expression. The allegory of metamorphosis, manifested in the protagonist's evolution, is a symphony of understated profundity, leaving an indelible mark on the player's psyche.

The gameplay mechanics of "Changed" are a testament to the adage that less is often more. The minimalist controls belie a complexity that mirrors the existential quandaries woven into the narrative fabric. Every encounter with the enigmatic denizens of this digital realm becomes a dance of evasion and assimilation, a tactile ballet that mirrors the thematic core of transformation.

The atmospheric soundtrack, a melodic echo in the corridors of silence, envelops players in an auditory embrace that heightens the emotive resonance of the journey. Each note, a haunting whisper, becomes a companion in the solitude of change, underscoring the emotional depth of this minimalist masterpiece.

"Changed" stands not as a conventional game but as a digital parable, an exploration of identity and transformation that transcends the boundaries of traditional gaming norms. It is a testament to the evocative power of simplicity, a journey that resonates with an understated elegance that lingers in the recesses of one's contemplative consciousness. In the pantheon of indie gaming, "Changed" emerges as a whispering enigma, inviting players to peel back the layers of its enigmatic narrative and uncover the profound truths that lie within the silence of change.

149766627.review:
Changed Original Edition: It was a coin-toss on whether to recommend this game or not, because on one hand you have an extremely well-written story, told in a way that isn't just pages of hand-holding dialogue, and I absolutely loved that side of this game.

But.
And this is a big but.
The puzzles in this game are difficult, verging on unfair at times. The actually puzzle parts are usually of a pretty good difficulty, but the chase and movement puzzles require so much RNG that it ends up being extremely frustrating. My hours played at the time of getting my first ending was about 7.5 hours, but the actual time on the save file was only about 1 hour and 45 minutes, because you will be restarting multiple times on every puzzle, because it takes some time to learn ideal routes, and then you have the RNG aspect which adds even more resets.

In the end, I recommend this only if you can handle some truly infuriating moments and many hours of frustration, because for me the story is just barely worth the pain, lol.

149755335.review:
A Dark and Challenging Metamorphosis

Rating: ★★★★☆

Changed is a unique and unsettling experience that delves into the realms of body horror, transformation, and survival. It's not a game for the faint of heart, but it offers a compelling and atmospheric journey. Here's a four-star review that captures the essence of Changed:

"Changed is a game that's unlike anything else you'll find on Steam. It's a story of transformation, survival, and body horror that takes you on a dark and mysterious journey. The game's atmosphere is eerie and unsettling, drawing you into a world where nothing is as it seems.

The core gameplay centers around exploration, puzzle-solving, and encounters with bizarre creatures. As you progress, you undergo a series of grotesque transformations, each of which grants you new abilities and challenges. The sense of progression and change is a central theme of the game.

The pixel art style is detailed and effectively conveys the otherworldly and disturbing nature of the game's setting. The sound design and eerie music add to the atmosphere, creating a sense of tension and dread.

Changed's narrative is intentionally obscure, leaving much to the player's interpretation. This can be a strength, as it encourages discussion and exploration of the game's themes. However, it can also be frustrating for those looking for a more straightforward story.

The game's difficulty can be quite high, and some players may find certain segments challenging. The lack of clear instructions and the trial-and-error nature of some puzzles can be polarizing.

In conclusion, Changed is a thought-provoking and unsettling journey into the realms of transformation and body horror. It's not a game for everyone, but if you appreciate atmospheric and challenging experiences and are open to exploring darker themes, it's a title worth considering. It's a unique and memorable adventure that will leave a lasting impression, for better or for worse."

149289447.review:
(English review is down below)
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -

Este juego tiene sus cosas buenas y malas, y por desgracia las malas son mayoritarias 
(Hay que tener en cuenta que es el primero juego del desarrollador, y que esto está siendo solucionado en la ''Special Edition'')

Las cosas malas del juego serían principalmente la confusión que te generan algunos sprites, la forma en que la se te presentan algunos puzzles (son dificilísimos y más de una vez vas a tener que tirar de un walkthrough, así que si lo haces no te sientas culpable), y la jugabilidad.
Sobre todo la jugabilidad, por la forma en la que está programado el movimiento del personaje se hace muy difícil el esquivar a los enemigos, que es la ''mecánica'' principal del juego, ya que no cuenta con un sistema de combate como otros muchos RPGs (Es algo que la verdad he echado en falta, pero contaría más este juego como una novela interactiva que como un RPG ngl)

Y ahora, las cosas buenas, que aunque no lo parezca, las tiene
Y se centran principalmente en la historia
Los personajes son carismáticos, no los más carismáticos del mundo, pero no están mal
El desarrollo de personaje es bastante bueno, y en general la historia (para no hacer spoilers), me ha encantado
(De los pocos juegos que me han hecho llorar)

Así que conclusiones: El juego está bien, a mí me ha encantado, lo recomiendo bastante por temas de historia y tal, pero si te esperas un RPG al nivel de Undertale, olvídate
Al menos en la ''historia principal'', veremos á ver con Changed: Special Edition, que cambian bastantes cosas
Eso y que 0/10 no te puedes culear a Puro
- - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - - -
(This review has been translated with google translator)

This game has its good and bad things, and unfortunately the bad ones are the majority
(Keep in mind that it is the developer's first game, and that this is being solved in the ''Special Edition'')

The bad things about the game would be mainly the confusion that some sprites generate, the way in which some puzzles are presented to you (they are very difficult and more than once you will have to take a walkthrough, so if you do, don't feel guilty), and the gameplay.
Above all, the gameplay, due to the way the character's movement is programmed, it becomes very difficult to avoid enemies, which is the main ''mechanics'' of the game, since it does not have a combat system like others many RPGs (It's something that I've really missed, but I would count this game more as an interactive novel than as an English RPG)

And now, the good things, which although it may not seem like it, it has
And they focus mainly on the story
The characters are charismatic, not the most charismatic in the world, but they are not bad
The character development is quite good, and in general the story (not to give spoilers), I loved it
(One of the few games that have made me cry)

So conclusions: The game is good, I highly recommend it for story reasons and such, but if you are expecting an RPG at the level of Undertale, forget it
At least in the ''main story'', we will see with Changed: Special Edition, that many things change
That and 0/10 you can't fuck Puro

148707097.review:
This review is of changed, not changed-special, I haven't played that yet
The story of changed is a decent story. Its told in a non convoluted way and there isn't any hidden lore that's required to understand the story. The characters are well written, being such a short game, there are limitations to how much you can develop a character but changed does it well. The motivations of Dr. K could be fleshed out more but enough is there for the player to connect with. Puro is a lovable character with clear motivations and enough character development for the player to form a connection with. The cleaning robot is a character and I will talk about it. The cleaning robot is a well done addition and doesn't feel forced, the interactions are cute [spoiler] and the character is used as part of a puzzle in a later portion of the game. [/spoiler] The game play is just the right amount of challenging while still being fun, the puzzles are challenging and unique.[spoiler] The tiger shark boss fight is decent, the boss has 2 attacks and they are fairly easy to dodge. The squid dog boss fight is more challenging and can be frustrating at times, there is a route that you can take to make it more consistent. [/spoiler] The endings are good, the two bad endings are at points in the game where they are sad and impactful. The themes of the game may not be for everyone but if you're a furry and/or are on the fence about getting the game you should, it's well worth the money.

What a strange game. 

Before I start, I must say that this game is not for me. I went into this game knowing that and played it with an open mind. there are 3 things that can make this game enjoyable based in the concept alone:

A. you are a furry
B. you are into latex/transformation/CNC
C. you find the idea of losing humanity to be a terrifying concept.

I fall into none of these groups so my time playing the game was more focused on the gameplay itself. the 'transfurmations' are always very suggestive and fetishistic to the point that it was hard to ignore the first few times. the first part of the game before the main setup had alot of fuck you moments where you just lose by interacting with certain things or fall into traps that you can ignore with knowledge. I feel like this game could be done in a half hour once you understand the gimmicks and the pitfalls. speaking of gimmicks, this games rooms are very gimmick based. you use an idea for a room, then make a harder challenge based on the idea, and then move on to the next idea. areas of the game don't mesh very well because of this. the lore of the game is fairly basic and the dialogue is not very engaging, but it's all serviceable. this game has alot of backtracking in order to continue the story, and the saves are not very well placed. there are some saves that exist only through 1 room transition with no threats before the next save and some saves that take place right before a massive block of dialogue that you then have to go back to hit the save again to skip.

Despite what I have said above I did have a good time playing changed. all 5 endings were either bad or melancholic, but the gameplay kept me engaged, puro is a silly guy and it was challenging without being too bullshit (I still used a walkthrough for some door codes).

6.5/10 not for me but a good game none the less. I swear im not a furry

148175589.review:
Definitely for adults. I don't know how or why kids around 15 and under find out about this game. I regret that they're exposed to the kinky imagery in it. I guess if they get into the furry fandom at a young age via the internet, like I did more-or-less, then that's how & it's another discussion. Either that, or someone in a Puro outfit shows up at children's school or function. Either way, I don't like or condone it. It's inappropriate.

That being said, I am an adult, and I did buy it for the latex TF kink and suggestive artwork as well as for the appealing art style and design overall. I also bought it for the music by SHIZI, and to discover what I'd later find out to be a very cute, tender and tragic story about friendship and survival in a post-apocalyptic world. The art style is distinct and memorable, and there is a genuine heart and soul to to the game besides the ostensible kink bait. I say this because you can enjoy the game just fine while skipping or not reacting to the "transfur" imagery, and instead focus on the character dialogue and relationships. With that alone, it's truly a fun and rewarding game, albeit heavy on the trial-and-error aspect on purpose; and it's a solid accomplishment from a very small indie dev team's first game. I'm very much looking forward to playing Changed Special when it's finished & getting the other endings and achievements for vanilla Changed in the meantime.

TL;DR: bought it for the nice visuals & kinky art, finished it for the sweet & heartfelt story. Here's to Colin, Puro and K. Don't play it if you're a minor or share it with minors.

Because this game was created in RPG Maker, your character only moves one tile at a time, has a janky hitbox, and where you move can be really unresponsive in a game where you're expected to make the most precise maneuvers to avoid what often comes down to pure luck. A quicker way to respawn after dying would also help make this game filled with trial and error a lot more bearable, but I guess using F12 to boot you back to the main menu is the best RPG Maker can do? It's a shame because this could've been good if it was made with an engine better suited to create the type of game this is trying to be. There is some charm to it, and it's very good for the dev's first game, but I could never recommend anyone to play this.

My son is three years old, and we've been trying to potty train him for a while now. Unfortunately, we've hit a major roadblock - his fear of the "skibidi toilet" You might be wondering what a "skibidi toilet" is, and honestly, I had no idea either until we encountered it. Fron what I've gathered, "skibidi toilet" is basically a new genre of youtube video about evil singing toilets. Basically think zombies but instead they're toilets that sing in your face. I was fine to let my son watch the videos at first, as they seemed innocent enough and fairly harmless, but they soon devolved into strange post apocalyptic material with grotesque toilets fighting in a war against mankind, so I finally intervened and cut him off. I thought that was the end of it, he can't watch the videos anymore so theres nothing to be afraid of. Well, I was wrong. This has since turned into a complete nightmare for us at home. We recently started potty training and he refuses to use the toilet now due to skibidi toilet. Whenever we try to put him on it he screams and refuses to go anywhere near it. We've tried explaining that skibidi toilet isnt real and our toilet is completely safe, but it seems like it's too overwhelming for him. We even let him decorate it with stickers, hoping it would make him less afraid, but no luck so far. It utterly breaks my heart to see him so anxious about such a simple thing that every child goes through. I'm not sure how to proceed from here. Should we give him more time and hope that he warms to the toilet, or is it better to try a completely different approach? I know every child is different, but has anyone else experienced something similar? How did you deal with skibidi toilet in your household, if you encountered it

147534152.review:
I recently picked up "Changed the Game" with high hopes, given all the hype surrounding it. I mean, who doesn't love a challenging game? However, this game took it to a whole new level, and not in a good way. If you thought "Elden Ring" and "Dark Souls" were tough, prepare yourself for a level of difficulty that's just downright cruel.

My primary issue with this game is its unrelenting difficulty. I don't mind a challenge, but "Changed the Game" is punishing to the point of frustration. It's like the developers took sadistic pleasure in watching players suffer. The lack of any reasonable learning curve makes it almost impossible for casual gamers to enjoy.

Additionally, the game lacks any form of accessible difficulty settings. I understand that some players thrive on extreme challenges, but for those of us who want to enjoy the storyline and explore the game world without feeling like we're banging our heads against a brick wall, there should be options to tone down the difficulty. It's as if the developers catered exclusively to the hardcore gamer crowd, leaving the rest of us feeling alienated and disappointed.

The graphics and story could have been intriguing if they weren't overshadowed by the relentless difficulty. I found myself unable to fully immerse in the narrative because I was constantly battling impossible odds. What's the point of having a compelling story if most players won't even get to experience it due to the steep difficulty curve?

In conclusion, "Changed the Game" is not for everyone. If you're a glutton for punishment and enjoy the masochistic challenge of games like "Elden Ring" and "Dark Souls," then this might be right up your alley. However, if you're looking for a more balanced and enjoyable gaming experience, I'd recommend steering clear of this one. It's a missed opportunity for accessibility and widespread enjoyment.

146370182.review:
Warning: Changed is based around what is essentially non consensual horny art with animalistic features, if that makes you uncomfortable at all you really shouldn't play this!
Changed isn't a good game.

Changed is what happens when you give an artist with no game development experience a game making tool like RPG maker. All puzzles are either way too obtuse or laughably easy, almost every chase scene is based on RNG and the dialogue replaying after every death makes every attempt that much more frustrating. Not only that but the story itself isn't that well written, it's filled with plotholes and spelling mistakes, english wasn't the writer's first language but you can still definitely tell that the game didn't have too much proofreading, this game's primary purpose wasn't being a RPG and it shows.
Now for the good part! I'm still recommending it after all!
Hidden behind all of the janky gameplay this game had one of the best character writing I have ever experienced, to a point where it makes the game hard to review without either giving it too many spoilers or unjustified praise. Every interaction makes you feel like playing more and all characters are written in a way where you can not only empathize with them but actually agree with their actions, different people WILL have different opinions on the story simply from their past life experiences and that's great! This is VERY hard to come across in games with a linear storyline and Changed executes it perfectly. The dialogue at times is genuinely heartwarming and the combination of the cute artstyle with the (frankly adorable) unintentional mistakes makes it have a personal feeling that you really don't get anywhere else, by the end of the game you really don't see it as a game with characters anymore, it goes out of it's way to make you treat Puro as a friend, and the usage of a blank slate character here works fantastically well, it does what Undertale couldn't and actually makes you feel like you're in that universe. I think this is best exemplified with the very first scene in the game:
You start the game with a very simple a basic area where you're introduced to the game, you familiarize yourself with the author's writing style and the game's controls, familiar to anyone that has been playing RPG maker games for a while. The first puzzle is seemingly just unlocking a door, easily identifiable by the simple artstyle. You interact with some white goo and right there you are immediately greeted by furry fetish art!
alright you got baited it's time to talk about yiff lmaooo
This entire thing plays as if it was an excuse to show you as much furry art as possible, ranging from the core transformation fetish which pretty much acts as the game's selling point to some good old stuckage, bondage and hypno that are practically required for furry visual novels, this entire game is so pawfully horny from the get-go that it has a cult following exclusively devoted to hating it (which is probably how you got here in the first place), and boy, you can definitely tell a furry wrote those scenes! Almost everything is written as if it was directly out of a furaffinity CYOA fic but that really makes sense when you consider the target audience here. The fact that this is gifted almost exclusively as a joke really isn't surprising when you consider just how much of the game is spent just describing what it'd be like to be transformed into a hot latex animal.

Still didn't leave the game page after all that? Good! Buy it! Go play the game! It's relatively short (took me 9 hours to 100% but I was really struggling when I started it) but well worth the price, I'd give it a 8.6/10 overall. The game really... STICKS with you
(get it?)
Also since you read all this here's my advice (that most people probably don't agree with): Don't play Changed-Special first, normal Changed has better writing by a longshot. DO play it after Changed even if only for the new transfurs though, the gameplay is way better and it solves most of the problems I have with puzzles but I'd still not say it's a better experience overall.

Big thanks for my man MemStride for gifting me this game!

Overall, 9/10, Puro's a gem.

I have mixed feelings about this game. On one hand, its clearly a fetish furry game with very explicit imagery that will disturb you if you arent into that kind of thing. Which is a problem. It makes it on the other hand all that much better, but as unintended horror game. But anyway, I am gonna delve into few things about why I would recommend but also not recommend this game.

DISCLAIMER: I aint a fuckin furry. But I sure as hell will be made into one if I continue. I bought this game for shits and giggles to troll my friends while I streamed it. Which I both regret and dont regret. 

Lets start with controls and gameplay. This is an RPG maker game. A chase/puzzle oriented game. DO NOT expect much in terms of controls. You will die. They are just that wonky. Its... infuriating at times. So you need a lot of patience. When it comes to puzzles, this game is either 300 IQ or I am just that retarded at times. Some puzzles are also made harder because of enemies which roles back to my first point with controls being absolute disaster. One problem is also how confusing this game is at times. You wouldnt you can get easily lost in RPG Maker game but I honestly had to sometimes google where to go.

When it comes to the story, I hate how good it is. It has no right to be this good. And its probably helped by the fact I took this more as horror because Jesus Christ was I mostly unnerved by the things some find "hot". I am not gonna lie though, I really like Puro. His scenes are always good. Probably because he is the only one who can talk. [spoiler] Well, there is one more character who talks but he appears almost only at the end [/spoiler]. Overall I love the story. Unintended horror, but still pretty good.

The music and sounds is where its at. Do remember to put the volume down a bit though because its very loud. But the sounds. The ambience. THE MUSIC. I love it, and I fuckin hate this game for it. How does a fetish game pull out better ambience and sounds then some other games.

This game surprisingly, has bosses. They are, alright. Most of the time they are just "run around like headless chicken" or try to figure out what to do.

Lastly, the graphics. Eh. They arent bad by all means, but they arent screaming "best looking game ever". I do like them though. Most characters are ofc, just straight up furry or throw latex at it and be done. I do like main antagonist and Puro design though. The environment can range from boring to good looking to "What eldritch monstrosity did I just walk into". 

Do I recommend this game? Yes. BUT. You either have to be precisely the audience that this game drives in (sorry, but furries are definitely one of them) OR you have to masochist with few expectations of unnerving horror shit happening. I would rate this as low 8/10 or 7/10 game. Havent played the revamp/remake which this title comes in with, I dont plan to aswell. Dont forget, this will be in your library, for EVER.

Despite of the reputation of Changed, it has became a major personal favorite in terms of story line and character design. Personally, I don't really focus on the "kinks" (since most people mainly focus about the transfurs) but I deeply put my focus more onto the story line and the essence of adventure the human has to escape the facility, the game also shows the essence of acceptance from one of a kind. 

The game can be considered as moderately difficult but can be overturned when you get used to the tactics and moves for every attempts you do. Changed does have a balance between serious and wholesome moments which should be recognized, Moments with Puro is a great example for this category. The lore within Changed was also interesting enough which people should also take such recognition of. For example : the segment of you, the player, asking Puro about several questions the game gives you, he would really explain the events that happened even before where the game takes places, the amount of detail behind these dialogues are just outstanding. The characters (despite of most of them being latex creatures) are also to be credited, some are simple while some are actually well thought of (like tiger shark) and this even became a major influence with OC designs. Some shows about their personality which fits in to the lore (some of the character's personalities are even mentioned through dialogues) while others are up for speculation which is still passable.

Overall, Changed is an outstanding furry-based game in terms of the story line, characters, and partially the symbolisms. Its just sad that most people pays attention to the "kinks" part of the game.

144322074.review: This game was great. Obviously, there are the weird parts of it (especially squid dog fight and death scenes) but the story, relationship, and difficulty make up for it. I still like the weird stuff personally but most won't. (Spoilers from here) The story was pretty good, with it mostly being dependent on your relationship with Puro, who is a black latex which studied language for a bit and is way smarter than other black latex's. At the beginning it is basic with you just waking up from a cryo-pod and looking around for survivors while being attacked by monsters. After getting through that stage, you meet Puro in a library. After that you do a bunch of difficult boss fights and chases with Puro always waiting for you somewhere. He does many cute things when you return to him after a fight/chase such as hugging you or resting with you. After all of that, you meet Dr. K who is the last scientist trying to stop the latex virus and has mostly failed but will certainly fail if you escape. He tries to stop you, but with the help of a cleaning drone and Puro, you beat him and get to go to the bottom floor. When you are at the ending, (BIG SPOILERS) Dr. K does a whole speech about how you shouldn't leave and how it would just destroy the last chance of humanity on the earth. So you get 2 choices, with a secret one I will talk about later. First, you get to stay in the tower, not risking destroying humanity but you are confined and most likely will be transfurred. Second, you can leave the tower to go outside but you risk all of humanity as you don't know if you carry the virus or not. The secret option you have to press ESC when it gives you the 2 options and it will begin a segment where you willingly become transfurred but get to stay fully conscious and are cured of the virus. This ending was great, especially at the end (of the ending I know) where you get to go with Puro into the world and live out the rest of your lives together. This was super cute too in my opinion. The only problems I had with this game is its absurd RNG sometimes and the delay between pressing the arrow keys and actual movement. Other than that, this game was perfect. 10/10 (soundtrack is also a banger)

142675548.review:
[h1] UwU-y Gooey Transfurmations! [/h1]

Alright, let's talk about Changed, an action-puzzle game that's definitely not your typical run-of-the-mill experience. It was released back in 2018 and developed by DragonSnow, with some interesting background music by Shizi. But be warned, this game has some kinky, fetish undertones, so brace yourself.

The plot is simple yet intriguing. You wake up in a research facility after being unconscious for who knows how long.

Your goal? 

 Escape. 

But here's the twist, everything in the facility wants to transform you into a latex furry. Yeah, it's as bizarre as it sounds. 

As you progress through the rooms, you uncover the backstory from various written materials and meet other characters with their own motivations.

The gameplay is a mix of puzzles and action sequences. Figuring out the puzzles can be a challenge, especially when the rules suddenly change without warning. Fail, and you'll face some rubbery transformations. But hey, that's part of the appeal for some players, right?

Visually, the game is simple but effective. The chiptune-style music adds to the tension during chase scenes and creates a calming atmosphere in other areas. The transformations are a major theme, and while some occur at the sprite level, others are displayed as full-screen images with more detail. Some of the transformations in the Changed-Special version even feature bondage elements, which might interest some players.

So, is Changed worth playing? 

Well, if you're into furry, latex transformations, this game might just be your cup of tea. But if you're person that's just curious and want to see what this game is about...  It's certainly not without its flaws. 

The puzzle challenges can be fun, but there are probably better puzzle games out there if that's your main interest. The real charm of Changed lies in the quirky transformations that happen when you fail. Just remember, it's not your typical game, so approach with an open mind and a willingness to embrace the unconventional.

Overall, its a good game and my curiosity has been satiated. Furry or not, the game does have a charming indie feel and you can definitely tell that this was a passion project at heart.

Equipment needed for making pie

(Amazon affiliate links) - Check out my favorite kitchen essentials.

    9" pie plate 
    rolling pin
    parchment paper
    whisk
    spatula
    pie weights or dried beans
    pie shield or foil
    mixing bowls
    measuring cups and spoons

When it comes to the perfect apple pie there are 2 questions you need to ask. What kind of apples are best for apple pie and how to get an amazing, flaky pie crust.
Best apples for pie

There are so many apple varieties to choose from when making apple pie. Here a few common varieties that you can find at your local grocery store!

    Granny Smith - These are the best apples for making apple pie because they are super tart and very firm. Firm apples hold up well during the baking process unlike varieties such as McIntosh which kind of turn to mush.
    Honeycrisp - This is my second choice when it comes to apple pie. This variety is super crisp, tart, sweet and holds up great during the baking process.
    Jazz - Another crisp and sweet apple variety.
    Golden Delicious - Widely available apple variety. Holds up well during the baking process but will be a little softer than the others.
    Jonagold - A little tart and sweet.
    Pink Lady - Just like Jonagolds, this variety has a good balance of tart and sweet.

The perfect pie crust

A great apple pie starts with an amazing pie crust. We love to use either this all-butter pie crust or our sourdough pie crust. Each of these pie crust use butter and just a little bit of vinegar to produce a tender, flaky pie crust that just can't be beat!

The crust can be made a few days in advance and kept in the fridge or frozen until ready to assemble your apple pie.

If you decide to use a store-bought crust, make sure to follow the directions on the packaging to determine when to take the crust out of the fridge in order to handle it more easily.
How to make apple pie from scratch

Peel, core and slice the apples. In a large mixing bowl, gently toss the apple slices, granulated sugar, light brown sugar, flour, cinnamon, nutmeg, lemon zest and lemon juice until well combined and set aside. Place the oven rack in the center position and preheat your oven to 400°F.

Remove the discs of pie crust from the fridge and let set at room temperature for 5-10 minutes. On a lightly floured surface, roll one of the discs into a 12" circle that is ⅛" thick. Place the crust into the bottom of the deep dish pie plate.
A pie crust being placed into a pie dish.

Spoon the apple pie filling into the crust, discarding any liquid at the bottom of the mixing bowl. Spread the apple slices evenly.
Apple slices in the bottom of the pie crust.

On a lightly floured surface, roll the second disc of pie dough into a 12" circle that is ⅛" thick. Place the crust over the apple pie filling.

Use a sharp knife to trim the excess dough from around the edge of the pie plate. Use your fingers to pull both the bottom and top pie crust up and slightly away from the edge of the pie dish. Fold the edge under itself and press down to seal the edge in place. Rotate the pie a quarter turn and repeat until edges are neatly tucked in.

Place the pie dish onto a baking sheet and gently brush the surface of the dough with the egg wash and sprinkle sanding sugar on top. Use a sharp knife to cut vents in the crust.

In order to protect the edges of the pie from over-browning, use a long strip of aluminum foil (about 38" long) by folding it in half lengthwise and then folding in half again, lengthwise. Wrap it around the edges of the pie plate and over the edges of the crust. This is referred to as a "pie shield".
A strip of foil around the edges of the pie keeps them from over-browning while baking.

Bake the pie at 400°F for 25 minutes. Remove the pie shield, lower the oven temperature to 375°F and bake an additional 30-35 minutes.

You'll know the apple pie is done when the crust is a lovely golden brown and the juice is bubbling up the sides of the pan.

TIP: I recommend using a pie shield during the first 25 minutes of baking instead the second half of baking to prevent burning yourself when placing the shield onto the pie dish.
How to store

The pie can be made up to 2 days ahead of time and stored, loosely covered, at room temperature or covered in the refrigerator for up to 5 days.

142536975.review: This game is incredibly great. The story is solid, the concept and world design is great, characters are very cool, and gameplay is fun. You get immersed in the story and ideas of the game, and the horror aspects are definitely there, despite it being somewhat lacking in horror, it still is there. But it doesnt need extreme horror to be good. The style the game uses is great. The remake called "Changed Special" is better, but the original still is good. Just dont fall for the misconceptions about this game! Claims that call it various nsfw things are wrong. While the game is mildly suggestive, and a bit more so in the Special Edition, so is countless things people and even kids enjoy that are more suggestive than this game. The "nudity" warning is there because of the fact the animals are animals and therefore dont have clothes, and the mild suggestive content. A lot of claims about hidden nsfw meanings have been debunked by the creator. The creator rated it 12+ on an interview and I would agree with that. I love this game! Thank you Dragon Snow for creating a classic.

The Lore/Designs:
 The Designs and Story behind the game are very nice In my own opinion, although the lore is kinda scattered and annoying to find if you don't want to click on every white group of 20 pixels.  Designs look nice in my own opinion although allaround kinda weird for obvious reasons.
The Gameplay:
Very bare bones.  Puzzles are innovative but sometimes flat out kinda annoying to figure out, mostly just holding the arrow keys and shift button occasionally F12 If you don't want to see, you know the *Art*, although I don't think this game is trying to appeal to anyone who wants a genuine gameplay experience.
The Presentation/Art:
Presentation of the game could've been very much more improved with a few cinematic elements and the pixel art of the game is above average.
Controls:
Very bad.  no keybind switching, clunky movement, and bugs when you try to do two actions at the same time, although I'm just shouting info at the void.
Overall, Don't buy this for the actual game, but I think everyone knows that's not why people buy this game.

One of the standout aspects of Changed is its thought-provoking story. Players assume the role of a character who undergoes a series of transformations in a mysterious and dangerous world in the process of the game. The game explores themes of identity, choice, and the nature of humanity, leaving players questioning their own existence and the consequences of their actions within the game.

The gameplay mechanics in Changed are intuitive and engaging. Players must navigate through challenging puzzles and overcome obstacles using the unique ideas acquired during the game. The game keeps you on your toes, constantly presenting new challenges and surprises that make the experience both exciting and immersive.

In addition to its intriguing gameplay and narrative, Changed boasts a hauntingly beautiful soundtrack. The haunting melodies and ambient sounds enhance the overall atmosphere, immersing players even further into the enigmatic world of the game.

It's worth noting that Changed is not a game for everyone. Its abstract storytelling and challenging gameplay may not appeal to those looking for a more casual gaming experience. However, for those seeking a thought-provoking and visually stunning adventure, Changed is an absolute must-play.

In conclusion, Changed offers a unique and immersive experience that pushes the boundaries of traditional gaming. Its captivating story, enthralling gameplay, and mesmerizing aesthetics make it a standout title in the genre. If you're looking for a game that challenges your perceptions and leaves a lasting impact, look no further than Changed.

141812055.review:
Part I: Naivety

While browsing the Steam Points Shop, i stumbled upon multiple items from a small game called Changed. i enjoyed the aesthetic of the depicted creatures and so i delved deeper. i read the game's synopsis and an idea popped into my head: "This game would be perfect to stream to my friends." i thought. "It's short, its premise is wacky, and haha latex furry game." How wrong i was, that this game would only lead to a few hours of entertainment. That it would have no lasting effects upon myself.

Part II: The First Impression

The game's premise is mysterious but simple: leave this complex. So many questions are immediately raised: "Where am i? Why am i here? Why am i being chased by latex creatures?" But your initial thought is to simply ignore the questions. Answer naively that it doesn't matter, that it's just a fun furry puzzle game. You don't yet know what is in store.

Part III: The Challenge

Early on, you'll find that the game's difficulty is inconsistent, that it raises and lowers randomly. Many puzzles will lead to your death. You will die again and again and again. But something strange was happening. As i died over and over and over again, i still felt compelled to finish this game, to beat the challenge, to understand the mystery. The game told me making it out of this place would not be easy, there were times i had to go back several puzzles because i missed something i needed to progress the story. So why did i stand in defiance to it? i don't know. i don't know. But i could feel myself... changing as i played.

Part IV: The Change

In the military, recruits are beaten down until they are broken and then recreated in the image of a soldier. Changed is much the same. This game has broken me down again and again and again. My spirit has been crushed. And in the stead of that person, a new me was made. Forged in the fires of this hellish game. i have come to care for the creatures of this world. i have come to be... a furry.

Part V: Acceptance

i know now that i was no match for the game. Much like Lin, the player character, whom i have seen get covered in the oozing latex and furrified hundreds of times, i too have become furrified. THAT is the true nature of this game. And when it came time for the game to end, i nearly wept. For i had become a Puro truther. Puro's pain had become my pain. i was assimilated. The game told me to get all the achievements. The game told me to purchase all the trading cards, to forge a badge, a badge to mark the game's victory over me. But why does defeat feel so liberating? This question i shall ponder for hours longer, as i complete Changed: Special Edition.

Visions of a wife, a pet, maybe even kids flood my mind; the only source of respite that warms me in my terror. However, the ending is always the same. Blackened ichor fills my mind as my dreams fade further and further away from me. Had it not been for the paralysis I could’ve chased this ideal, the path I could have taken had I done things differently. That path was shut to me now, my future, morphed into a terror of the unknown that now stands before me. It pools in the corner of my room, taking a form that I cannot identify, even its subtle whiteness masked by the dark hour of the night. This beast does not move, and does not attack me. Yet it watches, maybe understanding the position I find myself in, as maybe I am not its only victim. However, as days continued and my mind is yanked from slumber it amasses autonomy, slowly but surely as I give it thought and legitimacy in my mind. Every time I awaken it inches closer and closer, form growing longer as the perspective moves from farther away, to almost looming over me. Now these days you can hear the subtle cacophony of droplets hitting the floor, growing louder and louder as I try to free myself from my cell, a cell I put myself in. My self incarceration only I can blame myself for, and my death penalty one that I had agreed to. These days, the question isnt what the beast is, but when it will change me, and swallow me whole.

141688854.review:
Creative story that tells a fantasy tale of a destroyed world trapped within a research complex. Unfortunately, complex extends to the randomised and unforgiving movements of enemies within the first quarter of the game, and when combined with save-points that feel few and far between, makes for an infuriating introduction.

Luckily, that smoke dissipates and leaves behind a wonderful, Puro. Someone who understands your struggles and foretells a saddening backstory that unveils the determination to prevail and escape. From then, the game is a truly unique adventure with all the ups and downs to ride. 

A worthwhile indulgence for anyone with an anthropomorphic fascination that spews a wide spectrum of imagining creativity around every new scene. it is captivating and proof that new realistic graphics aren't needed if the story can stand for itself. 8/10 for me.

The story it tells between Colin and Puro is very amazing and definitely worth exploring by yourself i'll say about 80-85% of this game rides on the story (not a bad thing if you ask me), if you're playing this game for the first time it will make you tear up at points. The Boss fights are hard (so prepare to suffer) and unique with each their own transfur animation same with the enemies you encounter in the game (so prepare to suffer even more). There is a Changed Special Edition, but its still under development and will probably be finished around late 2023 or early 2024. You can try the Special Edition on your first playthough but ill suggest you play Changed before Changed Special Edition to REALLY see the improvements the Special Edition offers. 

Overall its a good game with a fantastic story its worth it if you ask me.

In 1667, John Milton would write the epic poem Paradise Lost with the help of his sister, who transcribed his words onto paper due to his progressing blindness. The epic, an extension of the biblical Genesis, was thought of to be a criticism of the British Commonwealth that serves as a warning for the values the British Commonwealth are losing that will make the "paradise that was lost."  The epic would go on to be cited and parodied several times, becoming one of the most popular poems among the likes of T.S. Eliot's The Waste Land or Poe's The Raven. 
American scholar Thomas Paine cites the poem in his 1776 pamphlet titled Common Sense, where he argues for British separation. Specifically, he quotes Satan pondering to himself, where he wonders what would happen if he attempted to seek forgiveness from God, thinking, "For never can true reconcilement grow where wounds of deadly hate have pierced so deep." Paine uses this line to argue that because of the wars and taxation the British placed on America, that "nature hath deserted the connection [between Britain and America]," and that it can no longer happen, but actually, I think it's talking about how my friend gifted this to me and how i now feel about him anyways 7/10

139839877.review:
A large majority of people have a very common ability of being into something due to the plot and relatability. I however cannot say the same. I've never binged a show, played a full game in one sitting, or watched an entire movie franchise. However this game was special, this game CHANGED me. I love Change because it was something I can relate to and enjoy the plot/character development.
     I've always had issues connecting to things, i would not consider myself normal by any means. I'm quite the recluse, I had my true passions from everyone, I hate talking about my sexuality and other personal things. However, after I had started taking this game seriously, I found myself really comfortable. I felt like Puro, I felt like Human. I felt myself portrayed all round. From my more submissive traits portrayed by Human, to my more masculine/dominate lustful traits portrayed by the "enemy characters". Puro especially i related to. leaving the pack to pursue what i wanted, even if it wasn't "Normal" or "Natural instinct". I also related to the bad parts of Puro: a loner yearning for a companion. Around 8 months ago I stopped pursing a chance of finding myself a companion. I had lost emotion for someone and I never wanted that feeling again so I suppress all emotions, almost becoming numb. However deep down, I wanted someone like Human to just stumble into my life like he did into Puro's. I want to trust, I want to feel, I wanted somebody there. This game was like looking into a twisted mirror into myself.
     Furthermore, in addition to the extreme and personal connection I have with the characters. It also helped me realize that everything will be fine in the end. Puro goes from being a smart, lonely fella often seen as a monster, to a really good friend/lover (depends on how you look at Human's and Puro's relationship). Seeing him go to what I portray myself as to someone I want to be, it feels me with hope. Hope for the chance to explore a boundless world with my companion, It gave me a hope for difference, it gave me hope for change, I had changed.

139673126.review: Okay so, I've played this game through twice, (I got the Bad Ending and True Ending) and all in all, a pretty okay game. The art is very unique, reminding me of a DS game like Rhythm Heaven, and the animation pretty good to boot. The story is quite cool, and the characters are nice too. I do have a bit of a distaste for the difficulty. This game is hard, and it gets really repetitive after dying over and over again, but there's not much you can do about that past letting you skip dialogue, and having closer checkpoints / savepoints so, I guess it's okay. The real problem I have with this game... The death animations. They're really- weird. They're strangely... sexual. It made me very uncomfortable every time the screens came up, and made me feel uncomfortable playing the game in general in fear of seeing another screen like that. The concept was there it really was. The idea of a living gloop running around trying to get you, and when it does it takes over your entire body transforming you into something not human, is terrifying. I thought it would be a horror game based of what I knew going in. And well, this game is a horror game to me, but for all the wrong reasons. The death screens ruin the game for me. Ignoring that fact though, (which is hard) the game was alright. Most of the music was a bop, and the diversity between the different infected people was cool. Just... god the death scenes. This game is gross.

138726803.review: I really want to like this game. To be honest, I'll probably keep playing it, if only to say that I finished it and feel somewhat justified for having spent money on it. But it is one of the most infuriating things I have ever tried to play through. The "puzzles" are only challenging because the slightest mistake leads to you dying and having to start over from the last checkpoint, which is usually farther back than it should be and stuck behind a cutscene or unskippable lines of dialogue. Half of the boss fights don't even have save points right after them. This means you have to trudge through the same scenes again and again only to keep dying to the same thing. Almost every single room has the threat of death and losing progress if you misstep or investigate the wrong item, often for seemingly no reason except because they can. The mechanics are not explained well and leave you trying to figure them out yourself most of the time. None of the chases seem to have any sort of consistency. It's purely luck whether or not you are able to succeed at them, and the enemies move so stupidly quickly that even the tiniest slip up causes you to get caught instantly with no chance for correction. Even if you don't appear to make any mistakes, you still end up dying half of the time. The game is difficult--and not in a fun way. It has potential, but it's nearly impossible to focus on the story or enjoying the experience when I'm too busy being frustrated about the gameplay.

Changed is a puzzle game that just truely surprised me, his content is clearly more attractive for furries, but the story in general may be appreciated to non-furry people too! 
 
Nicely made pixel art graphics, fluid animations, detailed characters, original idees, the game is made to make you feel in danger almost everywhere, if you keep your guard too low, you may be surprised at every traps! 

The multiples endings give to the player the possibility to think about what to do to get them all adding a small game time. 

Some parts of the game are hards, but with the frequent save spots, you won’t be too frustrated when failing somewhere, and clearly, it’s probably a bit strange to say that, but Changed do have the cutest game overs I saw in video games if you’re a furry! 😉 

The main problem I need to mention in this game is the too basics commands handlig who may be very frustrating when you do have the habit to play more sophisticated games with free movings, here, you’l just move by walking on squares on the X and Y axis making sometimes unjust collisions. 
 
To my thinking, this game is great, and definitly worth the price! So give it a try if you never done it before!

137914705.review: (ingame) To make a pipe bomb in Changed, you will need tape, a shoelace, vinegar, dry ice and nitrogen chloride avalible at your disposal. You can find these materials at your local hardware store. For the first step you need to take a suitable container for your explosive. For this tutorial, i am going to be using a plastic water bootle as an example. Place about 50 miligrams of nitrogen chloride in the bottle then insert your dry ice carefully. Mix your contents with about half a spoon of vinegar in the bottle. Close and shake your bottle careffuly and allow the dry ice to impact the cap. "Changed" is an iconic open-world game that revolutionized the gaming industry with its immersive gameplay, engaging story, and unparalleled attention to detail. From the moment you step into the vibrant streets of Vice City, you're transported to a world of crime, violence, and intrigue.

The game's storyline is one of the strongest aspects, with well-crafted characters, dialogue, and missions that keep you hooked from start to finish. The game's voice acting is superb, adding an extra layer of realism and immersion to the experience.

The gameplay mechanics are equally impressive, with an expansive open-world that allows you to explore every corner of the city, from the bustling downtown streets to the sun-soaked beaches. The game's driving mechanics are especially noteworthy, with an array of vehicles to choose from and a physics engine that makes every car, motorcycle, and boat feel unique.

Overall, "Changed" is a timeless classic that remains just as enjoyable today as it was upon its initial release. If you're a fan of open-world games with an emphasis on action, crime, and exploration, then "Changed" is a must-play.

Alright, just to get this out of the way, this game is not a puzzle game. Not enough so that it could be classified as such. There are a few chase scenes as you run away from enemies, which are fine on their own; however, these chase scenes usually start with 1-2 seconds cut-scenes, which cannot be skipped. This sounds manageable, unless you are struggling immensely with certain paths (like the white tail chase) because of the hard-to-manage controls. This results in what feels like an eternity wasted just waiting to fail again. After the first fail, doesn't it make sense to either let the cut-scene be skippable or just remove it entirely?
While the music isn't bad, after a while, it can get very repetitive, yet that is partially my fault, for sucking at the game. HOWEVER, some of the areas just don't have music, which was very strange. The sound of silence is very loud. 
The best part about this game (for me) was the slip-n-slides, which truly felt like puzzles, and not brute force. 
Lastly, for anyone wondering what this game should rated age-wise, M, M for Mature (17+), because there is no reason that anyone should have to involuntarily view these inappropriate images without consent. [The game does not give a warning about lewd images.]

P.S. I can now never use the word "change" ever again.
P.S.S. The main character is Texan, the sidekick is Scottish, and the main antagonist is muffled in way that makes him near-unintelligible.

The puzzle gameplay is top-notch, requiring careful planning and strategy to progress through each level. The puzzles are well-designed and never feel overly frustrating, striking a great balance between challenge and accessibility. The controls are easy to learn and responsive, making it easy to focus on the puzzles themselves.

But what really sets Changed apart is the romance aspect. The relationship between the protagonist and Puro is sweet and endearing, and the developers did an excellent job of making the romance feel genuine and believable. I found myself getting invested in the characters and their story, and was thrilled to see how things progressed as I worked my way through the game.

The visuals in Changed are also worth noting – the game has a unique and eye-catching art style that really brings the world to life. The characters are all well-designed and expressive, and the environments are full of detail and charm.

Overall, I can't recommend Changed highly enough. It's a perfect blend of puzzle gameplay and romance storytelling, and it left me with a warm and fuzzy feeling in my heart. If you're looking for a game that will both challenge your mind and warm your heart, you can't go wrong with Changed.

136993925.review:
It was 10pm one april evening, and I wasn't tired, but I wanted to play a game in my backlog. Decided to finally give Changed a shot.

If you want the tl;dr:
~ This game can be VERY frustrating, with some puzzles being cryptic (You might need to pull out a guide), the chase sequences seemingly based on RNG. It might feel unfair at times.
~ But this has an intriguing, fun story, great art style, great music, it's funny, cute, and If you're even mildly curious, give it a shot!
~ If you don't like the look of slimy, wet latex look, then you might need to look elsewhere, or look at some other footage online to see if it's for you aesthetically.


Longer review:
The screenshots really sucked me in, the art looked just so enjoyable! I was curious by these "gooey creatures" there, and your character turning into said creatures. I then decided to go for it.

What I got in the end was an endearing adventure on friendship and sacrifice. And I want more! Even after I've 100% seen everything. 

Waking up in your capsule, scared, alone and attacked immediately, sets the stage for a game that will not hold your hand.
From a moment that might be of respite, only to be turned around and actually hostile. There's no hope here, until you find a seemingly neutral monster that isn't going to attack you.


This game has really great artistic design. It feel's "ms paint like" old style flash game, but polished. I'm not sure if there's an actual name for this style, but when the game was trying to portray you feeling uneasy, I felt uneasy. When you felt scared? I felt scared. It's like this fear of the unknown. You don't know what's going to pop around every corner, or come out of the floor, walls or anything.
I'll be honest too. I don't normally like the wet latex look. The idea of sticky, slime blobs and slime and stuff like that creeps me out, makes me feel uneasy. Knowing that the creatures "assimilate" you made me feel incredibly uncomfortable at first. The thought of your player being only wearing shorts the whole game, no shoes or shirt, the thought of getting this latex on them just made me incredibly uneasy. But after a while, I dig it actually, and I grew to like it!

The music, sound design, I thought it fit well. Atmospheric, and the music really fitting the experience too! I enjoyed this aspect, and I found new favorite chip-tune music to play!


But I want to probably bring out 2 of the most decisive parts of this game I feel. 
1: I had to pull out a guide on some parts because some of the puzzles felt too obtuse, cryptic to actually get through. Although I'm not the most proficient with puzzle games so your mileage may vary.

136494738.review:
Changed review by Ender

I got to play this game as a dare I took from a discord user. I expected it to completely destroy my sanity. I was suprised. I enjoyed playing this game a lot, comparable to my favourites, like Hollow Knight, Celeste, Terraria, Rain World and many more. I'm going to seriously review this game now. Be careful, some minor spoilers ahead.

The furry aspect of Changed
So this part is probably why you are reading this. And uhm~ fair I guess. The game is clearly oriented around the concept of furries And it's true. Changed gets dangerously close to the "suggestive" border. Before I played it, I expected it to uhm~ cross the border. I hate to clarify it again, but I was DARED to play it, and I take dares seriously. I am NOT interested in any freaky furry stuff. I really hope that's clear to everyne. One of the main concepts of the game - transfurmations is uhm~ interesting. Basically, you lose the game when you get touched by certain enemy creatures. Upon death, you get transformed into an anthro- thing. They all have their own animations.

Fuck why is this game fun - the gameplay
The gameplay mainly consists of running away, solving puzzles, etc. Basic rpg stuff. My main point is that Changed is NOT an easy game. I love hard games, and reseting hundreds of time just get to the next part of the story might not be for everyone, but it is something for me. The savepoints are fair and not frustrating. The puzzles are decent, not always very fun, but they are great still.

Im crying rn - the story
As much as the concept of the whole game is uhh~ questionable, the story is just amazing. I love it, the characters, the world, it's dripping with emotions (no pun intended :clyde: ). You can see the motivations behind each of the three characters very well. The aren't much decisions to make in Changed, but when there are, you feel an extreme weight behind them. I loved the ending of the game the most, it felt very emotional and I loved it. I've grown very attached to those characters, and i felt their reasoning very well. This was truly one of the best pieces of storytelling I have ever experienced, along with the games like Celeste or Hollow Knight. Changed is amazing at making you feel emotions they want you to feel. The despair, hopelessness and powerlessness of waking up in an unfamiliar, dead world, with everything trying to "change" you makes you really enjoy those moments when you find someone who you can trust and who can help you.

Artstyle
Cool ig, reminds me of OneShot. I just don't really understand why they had to make multiple animations of the player being turned into furry creatures

Number summary
Gameplay: 8/10 (it was hard)
Story: 10/10 (very emotional)
Graphic design:7/10 (decent ig)
Characters: 10/10 (puro ^w^)
Music: 9/10 (i love 8bit and chiptune)

So, basically I would recommend you to play this game, but be warned of the "transfurmations" uhmm~ they might make you feel a bit uncomfortable , if they dont, then theres something wrong with you.
I can safely compare this game to OneShot, though it isn't fourth-wall-breaking.
Cya.

This game has a certain... charm. The art style is cute, as are the characters and interactions. My heart was kept rather warm for the duration of the game (at least as far as I could make it.) And obviously the game will probably awaken... something, within you. The only issue is how unbelievably infuriating the actual gameplay can get. 

The game was apparently made in RPG Maker XV. It utilizes an invisible grid system for movement, which is honestly the entire problem. There are multiple chases and puzzles to complete while being harangued by wandering enemies. The issue is you have to be absolutely *perfect* with your movements and placements, which isnt easy when the grid system isnt displayed and you constantly are catching on invisible grid corners or hitting enemies hit boxes without realizing it. It doesnt help that the movement controls seemingly cant be changed from the default awful arrow keys to WASD. Why I must use the arrow keys when I almost never do in any other game, I do not know.

 I made it as far as probably 75% of the way through the normal difficulty version and got to a point where you have to simultaneously dodge floating enemies and stationary obstacles, all while a robot mimics your movements in a different area. You have to make the robot navigate a course with YOUR movements while UNABLE to see it half the time. So while my eyes are on it (or Im trying to get the camera to pan to it), I get hit with an enemy or blunder into a trap on my side. I gave up, as this was probably the fifth time I was filled with frustration just trying to get past one area. I was even following a walkthrough play by play. 

Is it all a skill issue? Sure. I admit I sucked at this game. But I ran out of steam, and I bet many people will too. Until the next "special" version comes out that supposedly lessens the difficulty, I cannot recommend this game.

135752978.review:
I have really enjoyed this game. I had already watched Neco the Sergal on a few episodes before playing but I found out it's quite a good puzzle game with an interesting story; I was really worried it would be super fetishy and stuff but it's fine. I do think anyone can enjoy this game but people who like anthromorphic animals will enjoy it more as the person who made it is a furry I think.

Some of the things I enjoyed: I think the game really nails the ambience, you truly feel you are in a apocalyptic world rather than just being in one especially when you go outside.  I also really enjoy the retro styled art the developer used; and also DragonSnow's friend SHIZ I think made an excellent soundtrack to match it. The latex beasts are awesome too and the art they have. 

I do think the most important aspect of Changed is its benefit on people's mental health. I think in this hard world, you need this kind of escapism to help you release all the pain you have and keep you going. I think mental health within the furry community is generally quite difficult because when going through stresses, you desire that certain someone who's a anthro to help you out. I know I wish there were literal anthros walking around but know that it ain't true. However, your relationship with Puro is that someone in Changed who is that anthro helping you in life. I know that was a bit of a tangent just to talk about Puro but it's the kind of escapism that helps me get all that stress off my chest and keep me going. I know this is a bit cheesy but maybe you have experienced or will experience the same thing while playing this game.

Regarding the endings, I'll try not to spoil anything but some of them are quite gut-wrenching especially with the context. However, a bit of a negative are the conditions to get some of the endings; you'll probably need to read up a guide after getting a bad ending to see where you went wrong. I recommend saving in different slots so you can choose the best point to try and get the other endings. The conditions are mainly to do with your interactions with Puro but with the best of intentions (and for someone like myself who loves Puro to bits) it's extremely difficult to get a good ending without looking up guides.

I think there are some sections of this game that were really difficult. I know some people talk about the difficulty of the squid boss but I thought the shark boss was harder. There was one puzzle to find a code that I would never have found out without a guide but majority of them I could work out. It takes a bit more thinking but quite satisfying when you work it out.

To summarise, I love this game and love the anthro aspect of it. I do recommend this to furries but also non-furries too who like a warm but tear wrenching game with puzzles and a bit of action. The game will only take you 2 hours to complete if you know what to do but it took me 12 hours as there's a lot of puzzles and difficult parts that take a number of times to do. I'm also looking forward to the special edition when DragonSnow releases it. The awesome thing is DragonSnow is very passionate about his game and I'm sure he'll improve on a already awesome game.

Also thank you so much for making a game that touches my heart. I am deeply grateful for this game and has helped me out in life so much. I wish all the best for the developer and hope he continues to find success in his game development career!

135523996.review:
Bought this game because I need 2+ hours of playtime to buy the game's associated items in the points shop.
Just 5 bucks, no big deal. And I need those 2 hours, so might as well give it a shot, right?

Sadly, I do not recommend this game for a variety of reasons.

As for the menu:
No resolution control, no audio control, no changeable keybinds, no nothing.
There's really only two buttons you'll be using outside of your arrow keys: shift for run, z for interact.
Both of which I have an issue with.
1 - Forced to use z even on qwertz layout.
2 - Outside of sneaking areas you'll hardly ever let go of shift. All it does is tire your pinky.

As for gameplay:
There's two difficulty options, easy and normal.
The timings on chase sequences are very tight, even on easy difficulty, making me wonder why it exists in the first place.
Particularly since choosing easy will end the game at the halfway mark and lock you out of the true ending. Why?
The way to progress is not through skill, but trial and error, and some encounters are entirely RNG based.
You get a key - F12 - to skip death scenes, but you cannot skip the cutscenes ahead of chases, which you'll be rewatching a lot.
You will encounter button mash mechanics that are designed to f*** with you.
The abundance of insta-kill obstacles, particularly in safe zones, is more of a nuisance than anything.
Additionally it is very easy to accidentally brick your save file by saving in the wrong spot in the wrong moment.

Changed advertises itself as 'high difficulty' and is designed to test your patience. But even when compared to typical rage games in the I WANNA format, Changed does not hold up. All in all I've been mostly left with a feeling of frustration rather than accomplishment. Changed is not made to challenge you, but to p*** you off.
This is a crudely made game worth ~20 minutes of playtime, not accounting for the additional hours of trial and error, with little love put into it looking at the complete lack of basic game settings, and the various grammatical errors within the dialogue.

The only redeeming quality here are the stickers you can get from the points shop. That aside you can find better games for free.

135286740.review: Short review: If you are really looking for a rather odd and obscure indie rpg then this isn’t a bad choice. (Spoilers) Longer review:I bought Changed simply because I thought it was a weird furry game that I could stream to my friends as a joke, but also partially because I was curious as to whether or not the game had something more to offer. I was honestly surprised with how much more effort was put into the game than I anticipated. The gameplay and its mechanics are relatively simple. You explore, solve puzzles, and dodge monsters. However, it still manages to be very challenging. You will most definitely be spending a lot of time doing certain areas on your first play through. I would say that the majority of the games puzzles and other challenges are at least somewhat enjoyable  (though some are rng dependent). Some memorable ones include the very first password puzzle, the chase sequences, and the two water level bosses. You essentially avoid fighting directly against most enemies. The monsters and areas you will see along the way are unique, even if they are similar to previous versions. Again, the gameplay is simple but it still works. The OST isn’t anything I would listen to on it’s own but the simple tunes can be nice to listen to in game. Now for the main draw of the game, the story. You play as a human who wakes up in an abandoned tower with little to no recollection of what has happened. The tower is a research facility and it has latex furries wanting to infect you. You journey through these obstacles to escape as you also figure out what has happened to the outside world. Along the way you meet Puro, a silly talking latex furry. He’s important to the plot as he influences every ending in the game. (You pretty much have to be nice to him or your run will cut short) At the second half of the game you and Puro work together to escape until you are stopped and captured by Dr. K another talking furry that was once a human. He explains how the research facility is meant to find a treatment to a disease that almost wiped out humanity and that you may have the virus. If you were nice to Puro, Dr. K will be knocked out. giving you time to escape. At the end, Dr. K confronts the player once again to give them a choice to either stay and sacrifice yourself for humanity or leave with Puro and risk dying. The story is quite interesting with its sci-fI aspects and it’s focus on the relationship between the human and Puro. Overall, I would say Changed isn’t a bad game when you look at it with an open mind. If you can ignore the fetishy aspects then it can be a just a nice game that may give you a new perspective on furry’s (not joking).

This game is an RNG Fight from hell. If you know how RPG Maker AI works, you can imagine why this game would be infuriating. You will spend way longer in sections than you'd like if it involves the "Chase" AI, because AI doesn't have a consistent pattern and this game has a tile based movement system. Sections that don't SEEM hard will be infuriating simply because you are losing through no fault of your own. You can't predict the AI, so get ready to do the same section over and over with overly long death sequences because the developer wants to push his weird transformation fetish on you.

The story is fine, but you'd be better off watching a YouTube walkthrough if that interests you. Music however, is stellar. Absolutely no complaints, I love the soundtrack.

134974119.review:
[h1]Notes[/h1]
This is a review about the classic version that may be replaced by the special version anytime soon.

[h1]Overview[/h1]
At first I was kinda unsure about playing this game, because most people say it's an eroge and it even has sexual content tag on Steam, and I wasn't in the mood to play NSFW. But in the end, even though there are some suggestive scenes, it doesn't really have anything that lewd, it's actually much softer than the ecchi you normally see in anime. There's nothing sexually explicit, it's actually pretty cute and wholesome and has some Undertale vibes to it. It's one of the best indie games I've played, just wish it was longer (but looks like the special-edition will fix that).

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Quite simple 2D game where you basically just have to walk around and interact with things, you also have to run once in a while.

[h1]Graphics[/h1]
The game is entirely in flat color pixel art, it has good quality and some cutscenes feature even more detailed pixel art.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The soundtrack is quite nice and it fits well with the atmosphere of the game. The sound effects are okay.

[h1]Price[/h1]
The game has a fair price for the content it provides.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
The game is mostly linear so it isn't hard to find everything and most of the puzzles are easy as well, although some may take a while to find out what you need to do. There are some parts where you need to be fast, which can be challenging, but nothing impossible.

[h1]Duration[/h1]
The game is a bit short, even if you explore everything and want to get all endings, but the upcoming special edition will add a lot of content so it will be a little longer.

[h1]Replayability[/h1]
You may want to play again to get an ending you lost or just to see some game over scenes you haven't seen in your previous run.

[h1]Achievements[/h1]
They are fairly easy to get, you just need to get all endings, which are quite easy to achieve.

[h1]Problems[/h1]
In the Portuguese version, there's a puzzle you can't normally solve because of a mistranslation, the only workaround is to search for the answer on the web.

133827840.review:
In a certain part of the game, you will find a hidden room that you have to discover in order to continue playing. A room that you not only have no way of knowing how to access but also cannot deduce that it exists. Or in a part where you have to guess the password of a machine and the note that has it is hidden on the side of the machine (all very fair). Needless to say, anyone serious about a good puzzle will not like this. And if it turns out that you are saving like a freak/hating this game: Your save point brings back with it all your previous progress; If not careful though, you may have to replay an entire section you've already passed because of unfair puzzles or traps placed so they cannot be seen by players who are not good at solving them.
The only thing I took away from the game is the music, which I found retro and enjoyable. The characters are decent but do not have the same level of detail as those in other games. The settings are also below average; although they were colorful and diverse, there were still several things missing from them. Finally, the main incentive to play was the story--although it was interesting and engaging at first, it soon became overshadowed by all of the other problems that I've mentioned before. In conclusion, this game needs to be fixed. Although it entertained me for a while and I congratulate the creator on his creative abilities, it is not easy to make a video game; They should definitely consider making changes to improve the game before releasing it again.

America, 1899.

Arthur Morgan and the Van der Linde gang are outlaws on the run. With federal agents and the best bounty hunters in the nation massing on their heels, the gang must rob, steal and fight their way across the rugged heartland of America in order to survive. As deepening internal divisions threaten to tear the gang apart, Arthur must make a choice between his own ideals and loyalty to the gang who raised him.

Now featuring additional Story Mode content and a fully-featured Photo Mode, Red Dead Redemption 2 also includes free access to the shared living world of Red Dead Online, where players take on an array of roles to carve their own unique path on the frontier as they track wanted criminals as a Bounty Hunter, create a business as a Trader, unearth exotic treasures as a Collector or run an underground distillery as a Moonshiner and much more.

With all new graphical and technical enhancements for deeper immersion, Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC takes full advantage of the power of the PC to bring every corner of this massive, rich and detailed world to life including increased draw distances; higher quality global illumination and ambient occlusion for improved day and night lighting; improved reflections and deeper, higher resolution shadows at all distances; tessellated tree textures and improved grass and fur textures for added realism in every plant and animal.

Red Dead Redemption 2 for PC also offers HDR support, the ability to run high-end display setups with 4K resolution and beyond, multi-monitor configurations, widescreen configurations, faster frame rates and more.

I was still able to enjoy the game, but I do not recommend it.
