That being said, it is excruciatingly difficult, with challenges that are hard to solve, sometimes relying on guesswork even. The action segments are often frustrating due to trial and error and input issues (it's made in RPG Maker). The story is shallow and the game is only 6-10 hours long, with a lot of the length depending on puzzle solving skills. The save points are also usually far from challenges, which feels really annoying. 
Probably the thing you might be most interested in, which is the art, is actually pretty middling and relies on being a fetish to bring value. The death animations and post transformation art are limited, and the quality isn't outstanding either. It is pretty much what you paid for, at this price point.

I can recommended it only for those who enjoy the artistic content. If you were gifted it by friends, it can be fun with them in voice chat, as they can help with puzzles and laugh at the challenges. 
In the end though, it is not recommended for non-furries (and probably even many furries) looking for a good game, as it is often frustrating and just plain not worth the price.

The Omega is an E-segment passenger car manufactured and sold by Opel. A sedan and a station wagon were available, with rear-wheel drive. Its predecessor was Recolt.
It was positioned next to the Senator, Opel's flagship at the time. Despite competing with the likes of the BMW 5 Series, Mercedes-Benz Medium-Class and Audi 100, Opel stopped producing the Omega in 2002 and has since exited the E-segment.The second generation model, Omega B, appeared in 1993 (sales in Japan began in 1994). Adopted a bolder aero look. The body was enlarged to integrate with the Senator, and the body shape was a sedan and a station wagon. In addition, the long-lasting in-line 6-cylinder engine was replaced with a newly developed V-type 6-cylinder engine.
In the UK, the Carlton name was abolished and replaced with the Vauxhall Omega, similar to Opel.
It was improved every year in 1996, 1997, 1998, and in 1999 (Japan specification from 2000) minor changes were carried out. The design of each part has been changed to show dignity suitable for Opel's flagship, and the slightly too aggressive design has changed to something that is more acceptable to conservatives. The interior was also changed from an instrument panel that used many curves to a straight line design. In Japan, it is commonly called 2000B after minor changes. In the home country, a BMW 6-cylinder diesel engine was also set. In addition, a model equipped with the same V-type 8-cylinder 5.7-liter engine as the Chevrolet Corvette was also released for a limited time.
At the time, GM's Cadillac division sold sedans under the name Catera to compete with BMW, Mercedes, and the newcomer Lexus in the United States, but sales were poor. The Catera was discontinued in the 2001 model year, and the following year it became the Cadillac CTS, although it was the same rear-wheel drive car but adopted a newly designed platform called Sigma Architecture. CTS stands for "Katera Touring Sedan".
The models officially imported to Japan are as follows. A sedan or wagon body shape could be selected for all grades.
- Omega GL
In-line 4-cylinder DOHC engine 1,998cc 136 horsepower
A rare model that was introduced in the middle of the model life and dropped out of the catalog due to minor changes.
- Omega CD
V-type 6-cylinder DOHC engine 2,497cc 170 horsepower
A core model of Omega B. It was the best-selling grade.
- Omega Sport
V-type 6-cylinder DOHC engine 2,596cc 180 horsepower
Appeared at the end of the model. Based on the CD, the displacement was expanded and the engine management was changed. At the same time, the suspension and brakes were strengthened, and it was a sports-oriented grade that enhanced driving performance.
- Omega MV6
V-type 6-cylinder DOHC engine 2,962cc 210 horsepower
Omega's top model. Since the Senator has been abolished, it is effectively Opel's flagship.

Absolutely BEAUTIFUL game with pretty fun mechanics when traversing the facility, each death is pretty unique and interesting to see what each of them are. When on easy mode it would be like playing on normal difficulty but on normal it's HARD. 

Unless you are skilled in movement in games you will have a ROUGH time but it has learnable methods to complete the game and each new section is pretty fulfilling with different ways to, well, change you.

The story of the game is alright, it's not like reading a massive novel with thousands of pages and it isn't like a child game where the only bit of story is a characteristic. What I mean by this is that the game gives an interesting plot that doesn't go on forever and the endings are well thought out and go well with the story.

Let me be honest I mostly wanted to play this game because fluffy boys and I LOVE the sharks however, the boss fight is pretty difficult but the AI does have a weakness of a pattern movement (I'm sure you'll find out).

in all seriousness this is NOT a game you should play as your first ever game, this is because of how difficult the game is as a whole. While the pretty style is aesthetically pleasing, the puzzles are hard and progressively get harder. The cat, actual pain I had experienced, I beat the game as a whole in a couple of days (taking breaks out of anger from boss fights as I have anger issues) and when I go back to the start I still get pain because of the cat.

I am pretty hyped for the changed special edition and wish the best to DragonSnow and the future of this lovely game.

130458424.review:
This is a not-fun and awful fap-bait game, albeit with some redeeming qualities. A game not being fun is the most scathing insult I can make towards a game. Note that I didn't play the special edition, but from what I can tell the only notable differences would be that the game would be slightly less of an eye-sore and slightly easier.
Pros:
- excellent rockin' Gameboy-esque soundtrack
- if you're part of the 0.0000001% or whatever of the human population who is into various homo-erotic furry scifi transformations, this game sure has a lot of that for you to touch yourself to
- Puro is an interesting, cute, and fun character
- it has somewhat interesting sci-fi universe and setting
- it is dirt cheap when on sale, so if you don't like it and can't refund it, you don't waste a lot of money, just time.
Cons:
- the game isn't challenging in a fun way, it's just designed to kill you a lot to force you to watch homo-erotic "transfurs". Challenges are either based on going through an area a few times to learn what to do to not get insta-killed, RNG, QTEs, or exploiting bad enemy AI. It felt like a waste of time, unlike other challenging games. There was one especially poor fight, that based on RNG would make it impossible for you to win.
- the game gives you too much exposition telling you what you should be thinking and feeling. The game's "point-and-click" aspects could have been done a lot better, and would've been better with a more "show don't tell" design
- the game dialog and cutscenes and transformation scenes are unskippable, and to boot they're verbose and meander too much. This is a big pain-point, as if you're like me you'll die several times before getting though an area, and you'll be forced to go through dialog and transformation sequences over an over. After the first couple of times viewing dialogs or scenes, I just want to skip them so I can try the challenge again. Even though the game is generous with save points, they still don't feel like enough due to the unskippable dialogs.
- if you miss triggering several easily accidentally missable dialogs with Puro even once in the first half of the game, you essentially miss out on the second half of the game. I can understand triggering a different ending, but locking out half the game is overly cruel. If I actually liked the game, I would likely just play through it again "correctly" to unlock the second half, but the game sucks so I'm not doing that.
- the game's artstyle is garbage and looks like it was made in ms paint. It gets painful to look at after awhile.
- the game is chalk full of what appears to be shoved in OCs. Adding people's OCs is always a bad idea for a game, as the developer has to insert encounters in other than for good gameplay purposes. They ruin immersion, make the setting feel inconsistent, and are typically eye sores.

Pass on this game, watch a youtube playthrough, or visit e621 .

I bought this on a whim, so here's a non-sarcastic take:

Very much a latex transformation kink thing, but a solid game underneath. Not necessarily sexual imo.
Nintendo hard difficulty, as in a lot of random chance and near perfect movement is required to progress in some areas.
The story is VERY depressing and hopeless unless you get the true ending so it might be worth playing with a guide.

So if you got maybe 10 hours to spare, its worth a few bucks.
